paragraphs.text: You’ve probably by now seen the video of the doctor who was physically beaten and removed from a United flight because United wanted the seat for its employees. If you haven’t, here it is. Be warned: it’s an incredibly disturbing video:
paragraphs.name: ea17

paragraphs.text: So we’ve got the jokes about air travel being a hellish dystopia for anyone not in first class. We’ve got Wall Street cashing in on the metrics while ignoring the human horror of the story. And we’ve got “helpful” news stories explaining that in order to not have this happen to you, it’s wise to exercise some sort of privilege. It should be clear to anyone who’s paying attention that this story is not about customer service. It’s about income inequality. Helaine Olen posted a very good thread on Twitter about this:
comments
paragraphs.name: 401a

paragraphs.text: So we’ve got the jokes about air travel being a hellish dystopia for anyone not in first class. We’ve got Wall Street cashing in on the metrics while ignoring the human horror of the story. And we’ve got “helpful” news stories explaining that in order to not have this happen to you, it’s wise to exercise some sort of privilege. It should be clear to anyone who’s paying attention that this story is not about customer service. It’s about income inequality. Helaine Olen posted a very good thread on Twitter about this:

paragraphs.name: 500b
paragraphs.text: In plain language under Rule 25 — on page 35 if you print it out — the agreement says exactly what happens if the flight is oversold. “If there are not enough volunteers, other Passengers may be denied boarding involuntarily,” the language reads. (Of course, the deplaned man was not denied boarding, he was already boarded.) The language continues however, shining light on how these “other Passengers” are chosen. It’s not random, it’s “in accordance with UA’s boarding priority.” That means that if you have a higher fare class, have a complex itinerary, have status (e.g. gold or platinum), have checked in early, or are a frequent flier, you are less likely to be asked to take the next flight. Even if it’s just a frequent flier card that you never use, it might save you from being forcibly dragged off a plane.

I’m sorry, but anyone who’s already been seated should not be forcibly removed from a flight unless they’ve done something illegal or unsafe, not because of some BS class system. I understand how this might happen before boarding starts, but once you’re on the plane, that should be…

2e00c7a86b9.title: A complex itinerary doesn’t jive with class warfare criticism.

paragraphs.name: 7da8
paragraphs.text: A complex itinerary doesn’t jive with class warfare criticism. Neither does early check-in. And given the propensity of business travelers to have higher fare tickets, status, or be a frequent flier — it seems targeting passengers is less about class warfare and more about doing the least damage possible while maintaining some semblance of objectivity.

5b9674968995.title: I agree Americans at this point need to stop being party cheerleaders and unite for rights.

paragraphs.name: c6c2
paragraphs.text: I agree Americans at this point need to stop being party cheerleaders and unite for rights. If everyone boycotted United, we would see change in air travel. If every person put their money in credit unions, the big banks would struggle. If we boycotted healthcare as much as possible, change would occur. The people have power…they just have to use it.
